triples.name: Hilbert space
triples.relevance: The Hilbert space framework is the mathematical foundation for describing quantum states and the fragmentation structure in this work.

triples.name: Ergodicity
triples.relevance: The paper demonstrates ergodicity breaking as a central result of Hilbert space fragmentation in dipole-conserving systems.

triples.name: Conservation law
triples.relevance: Charge and dipole conservation laws are fundamental constraints that drive the Hilbert space fragmentation observed in the paper.

triples.name: Thermalization
triples.relevance: The paper studies the breakdown of thermalization as a consequence of Hilbert space fragmentation in dipole-conserving systems.

triples.name: Hamiltonian (quantum mechanics)
triples.relevance: Dipole-conserving Hamiltonians are the central objects of study for understanding fragmentation and non-thermal dynamics.

triples.name: Spin model
triples.relevance: The paper investigates one-dimensional spin-1 models to demonstrate Hilbert space fragmentation and ergodicity breaking.

triples.name: Quantum dynamics
triples.relevance: The paper studies the out-of-equilibrium dynamics of quantum systems with constrained conserved quantities.

triples.name: Dipole moment
triples.relevance: Dipole moment conservation is a characteristic constraint of fracton systems that enables extensive Hilbert space fragmentation.

triples.name: Invariant subspace
triples.relevance: The paper identifies extensive fragmentation into exponentially many invariant subspaces as the mechanism for ergodicity breaking.

triples.name: Eigenstate thermalization hypothesis
triples.relevance: The paper shows that dipole conservation prevents eigenstate thermalization, leading to non-thermal eigenstates throughout the spectrum.

triples.name: Quantum random circuits
triples.relevance: Random unitary circuit models are used for comparison to validate the fragmentation and non-thermalization results.

triples.name: Many-body localization
triples.relevance: The paper's findings about fragmentation preventing thermalization relate to many-body localization phenomena.
